AN EPISODE.

I.

(MABEL—AT HER DRESSING TABLE.)
I've lost my glove
Or let it drop by chance !
I had it last—oh! I remember—
Three nights ago at Bessie Wilson's dance,
While Ned was standing near
And with warm, pleading eyes
Besought me for a flower—
As trophy, sign or prize.
But I refused it ;
Told him "not to flirt 1"
Then stooped to see the stain
On my neiv velvet skirt.
Would he have dared to steal the glove
And keep it for a token?
But, dear! what horrid lurk it is
The new pair should be broken.
The others would have warmed his heart
Or filled as well the locket
In which—well,I declare 1
The glove's here in my pocket!

(NED—TO HIS PIPE.)
It was tempting. How tempting? Well, nobody knows,
As she stood there, eyes sparkling, cheeks
coleur de rose.
The flower I asked for—she said that she
wouldn't."
Yet even my dullness discerned that she
couldn't,
With old Mrs. Wilson, the tireless dragon,
Alert, vis-a-vis, with her tongue primed to
wag on.
Then over her frock, as she gracefully bent
To look at the stain, and, worse, at the rent
That I'd made when at supper, in feverish
rush,
I had wildly attempted to ward off the crush—
From her pocket there peeped just the end of
her glove—
The symbol in all time to lovers of love.

"CARJAC."
THE TROPHY ROOM.

In planning the gymnasium the trustees designed one room which should belong distinctively to the students. It was intended as a
place for the preservation and display of trophies won by Hopkins teams, and as a centre
for the social life of the students about the
gymnasium. The University, has provided
chairs and settees, a beautiful quartered oak
centre table, and a fine oak book case, and
have given the gymnasium committee permission to select engravings from the McCoy collection. Professor Adams has given a steel
engraving and gifts have been received from
the undergraduate classes. Many things, however, are yet needed.
A covering of some sort for the floor should
be provided, and a case in which the trophies
already available may be safely exhibited.
Racks for books and papers should be arranged and books on athletics solicited from
the generously inclined. THE NEWS-LETTER
will file the best of its exchanges in the room,
so that, in the accounts of their games with
other colleges, our athletes may "see themselves as others see them." Post-graduates,
too, may find these interesting. Appropriate
mantel ornaments—whatever, in fact, would
add to the attractiveness of the room—will be
highly appreciated.
These things will not come without effort.

Rev. Henry Van Dyke, D. D., LL. D.,
graduated from Princeton in 1873, and from
the Princeton Theological Seminary in 1877.
He also studied for two years at the University
of Berlin. In 1883 Dr. Van Dyke was appointed as preacher of Harvard University,
and in 1893 he delivered the Lyman Beecher
lectures on"Preaching"at Yale. Most of his
religious and philosophical works are read as
much across the waters as with us. His best
known critical work is the volume on "The
Poetry of Tennyson," published in 1889.

A MINIATURE.

By your own strict command and injunction
Your picture my wall may not grace.
Yet, alone, when gossips are absent
I may steal a swift glance at the face
Which art has made so like your own.
When the day's weary strivings are over,
And the duties that drive me are done,
And I sit in the firelight recalling
The deeds of the day, one by one,
And their measure of good and of ill,
Then I take from its guarded seclusion
That picture you gave me, dear friend,
And I make you the judge of my actions
And learn from your eyes if they tend
To the good, and the right and the true.
Full often your eyes seem to censure
Some deed, whose motive was mean;
Or an act, from honor diverging
Loses all its false glamour and sheen
'Neath the spell of your pure, maiden's glance.
God grant that the years may not lessen
Your faith in the strength of the right.
God grant me that time may not weaken
The mystic, the wonderful, might
Of a true woman's God-given power.

NEWS OF A FORTNIGHT.
HENRY GEORGE.

The session of the Economic Seminary, held
on February 25, was devoted to a study of the
life and writings of Henry George. Professor
Sherwood stated, on opening the Seminary,
that, however much public opinion may differ
as to the feasibility and practicability of
George's theories, neither his ability is doubted by one, nor the immense influence of his
theories upon public thought. From the efforts of George a new field in economics has
been opened up, in spite of the violent opposition of Walker and other prominent economists, who scouted the idea that such doctrines
could be included under the name of economics. Mr. Adams reviewed "Progress and Poverty," the greatest work of George. Mr.
Adams considered the fundamental defect of
the book was that it assumed everything static
except wealth and population. These premises
granted, George's conclusions appear logical—
but few will be willing to grant such conditions. Interesting reviews of various other
works of George were given by different members of the Seminary. In conclusion, Mr.
Niles, a prominent member of the Baltimore
bar, defended the single-tax theory. He considered it just that land, which is the primitive
form of wealth, should bear the burdens of taxation, while all other forms of wealth, since
they are created by man's exertions, should be
exempt. In other words, man's ingenuity and
thrift should not be discouraged by taxation.
Land, however, is not produced by man's exertion, and should pay the expenses of government from the "unearned increment of the
soil."

It is greatly to be regretted that the Legislature is faltering in the matter of appropriating financial aid to the University. There
is evidence of opposition to the appropriation
among a few people from the counties. This
can arise from only one cause—ignorance.
Misrepresentations of the kind that is given out
by that daily comic valentine known as the
World may influence some persons. This, of
all disreputable sheets, is at the top-notch of
yellow newspaper work. It deserves not to be
placed in the category of yellow journalism.
It is in line to say that all the other city papers
favor the appropriation. As to the merits of
the University's appeal, the strongest and
withal simplest argument is the list of some
thirteen hundred names of former students,
who have achieved prominence in business,
literature, science, medicine and law. There
is really no logical reason why the state should
not come to the rescue of the Johns Hopkins
University, which, more than any other institution in the State, has spread abroad the fame
of Baltimore and Maryland.
A committee of representative citizens from
Baltimore, of which Mr. Parr was chairman,
went to Annapolis in behalf of obtaining State

aid for the Johns Hopkins University. This
shows that the best citizens of Baltimore are
actively interested in the Hopkins, and we are
sure that this cannot fail to impress the Legislature favorably.
It is the intention of THE NEWS-LETTER
to take on its editorial board at Easter a few
members of the freshman class, that they may
have the opportunity to gain some experience and receive certain necessary training
for the proper carrying on of the work in the
coming year. By this association in the management with those already accustomed to the
work many of the difficulties naturally found
in the beginning of a year may be avoided, and
the paper will pass on to other hands without
giving undue evidence of the change, except
in what is hoped may be its steady improvement.
All of the men who wish to try for the position must write and hand in before Easter
some matter worthy of publication in THE
NEWS-LETTER. Any item of University news,
or an article on some question of interest to
the students here, may serve as subject matter.
By previous arrangement with the editor-inchief, some certain subject (as the hockey
games, etc.,) may be agreed upon. This will
test the fitness of the applicant for his work,
and among these applicants the new men will
be selected by the present board of editors.
rIt was decidedly a surprise. We have been
aware for a long time that the University authorities held a conviction unalterably opposed
to any undue levity of conduct on the part of
those younger children of the old "Mater," the
undergraduate youths. That this conviction
had been sturdily maintained in the teeth of its
greatest unpopularity we know. But that it
should have been promoted to the position of
an authorized dogma only when the issue to
which it applied had ceased to live was, we
confess, most unexpected to us. The regulation has unquestionably dealt the last blow to
hazing at this University and, perhaps, the
authorities felt that this coup de grace to an
issue of such importance, could not, in the fit-

THE NEWS-LETTER.
ness of things, be given by other than those
standing at the head of her body politic. Coup
de grace it was, in the truest meaning of the
phrase ; and while the Board of Collegiate
Advisors may enjoy to the full the knowledge
that it was they who drove home the last thrust
into the prostrate form of this old enemy, the
credit for laying that enemy low can belong
only to our student body. It was the student
body that, at Princeton, carried through the
honor system in examination. And it is undoubtedly true of all such bodies of maturing
young men gathered together in colleges or
universities that a radical change in their traditional customs can be effected by no cut-anddried rules, laid down for them ; but only by
the concerted action of the men themselves.
In the present instance, it was the freshman
class to whOm fell the opportunity of taking
this decisive step. And to them belongs much
credit. But credit is also due to the juniors,
who laid aside all personal feeling in order to
aid in what they knew was for the best interests
of the Hopkins ; and some crumbs of credit
should also fall to the seniors and graduates
who at the right moment assumed the right attitude toward the question.

President Gilman with the approval of the
Board of Advisers:
Notice is hereby given that any student will
be liable to immediate dismissal, who shall
hereafter in any way be an actor or participant
in hazing, or in interfering with class banquets,
or who shall engage, in the gymnasium, or any
of the University buildings, in any form of
disorder. Concerted absences from college
duties are likewise forbidden. With the unanimous concurrence of the Board of Collegiate
Advisers.
DANIEL C. GILMAN,
President.
Johns Hopkins University, March I, 1898.
While this is a very severe and decisive
action, it is yet for the best, as it eliminates
any possible misinterpretation of the faculty's
attitude, and should avoid all false representation, in the press, of the spirit of our University life.

a score of i to o, on Wednesday of last week.
The game was exciting from beginning to
end and on several occasions the individual
work was quite good.

LACROSSE.

On Tuesday evening last Captain Robinson called a meeting of the lacrosse coaches.
Mr. Sidney Cone, the famous Druid goalkeeper, was elected head coach. His assistants are Messrs Johnson Poe, Berwick
Lanier, Thomas F. P. Cameron, Thomas Penniman, L. Warrington iCottman and James S.
Hodges. The coaches discussed the style of
play to be used, and promised to assist the
team in the cage and on the field.
NOTES.

The Johns Hopkins University was admitted to the Inter-collegiate Athletic Association of Amateur Athletes of America. The
annual convention was held the 26th of February in New York. Messrs. Garrett and
Scholl were the delegates.
Now that Hopkins is a member of this Association it is necessary to send at least three
men to the inter-collegiate meet in order to
maintain its membership.
The furniture has been put in the smokingroom in the gymnasium. This consists of
carved oak chairs and a book case, in which
will be placed books on sports, and sporting
magazines. The pictures of the old athletic
teams will be hung on the wall, and the place
will soon have quite a cosy appearance.

MEDICAL SCHOOL NOTES.

Cards have appeared during the past week
announcing the formal opening of the "Book
Department." This concern, which promises
to fill a long felt want, is a private enterprise
managed by Messrs. H. W. Carey and E. H.
Hume of the first year. At present orders for
books may be left at the Postoffice, but later
on, the Department is to have a room in the
new Physiological Building. It has the active
support of the authorities, and text books used
in the different courses will be kept on hand.
Special books will be ordered for individuals,
and arrangements have been made with the
leading American and European publishers
insuring the prompt delivery of books ordered,
and where possible at a reduction from the list
prices.
This arrangement will save time, money and
trouble for the student, and should insure their
hearty co-operation and trade.
Messrs. E. H. Hume and E. A. Wells, of the
first year, have been appointed assistants in
Physiological Chemistry.
Y. M. C. A.

Mr. Morris 1.. Barr, our delegate to the Students' Volunteer'Convention at Cleveland, has
returned, and reports a successful convention,
in which 448 colleges and universities were
represented by 2214 accredited delegates.
There were 22 delegates from Maryland, of
whom four—Miss Rose Fairbank, and Messrs.
C. W. Otley, Joseph Akerman, and E. A.
Wells—were from the Medical School. The
Woman's College sent three delegates. The
large number of representatives from the Medical School is explained by the fact that a considerable number of the students are preparing for work as medical missionaries, and
hence are vitally interested in the students' volunteer movement.

dates for the team are, in the main, working
spiritedly for the success of their class. If reports are to be trusted, it seems as if our opponents had been more diligent in their practice. Still, the balance hangs so nicely that
we would advise no one to bet otherwise than
evenly. on either side. Both parties keep their
several points and arguments jealously concealed. We can venture to state, however,
that the Senate as a whole failed to refute
more than one of Senator Steam's arguments.
It remains to be seen whether the junior team
will be more skillful in its refutation than the
Senate. The Censor, with a great deal of insight, has announced that the arguments
brought forth at the contest would form the
subject for the final examination in forensics.
A large attendance from the student body is
thus assured. The last session will be employed for the final trial debate, in which three
men will take the affirmative, and three the
negative.
HOUSE.

The House met on Wednesday of last week.
It was virtually the last meeting, as the speakers on the team will take up the time at the
next session in showing the arguments they
have gathered. The team now consists of
Messrs. Morgan, French, Grimes, and Guggenheimer, and from these men the Censor
will make his choice as to who is to speak on
the day of contest.
The chief interest of the session centred in
the photographer of the Herald's staff. Two
pictures were taken—one of the team with the
advisory board and the volunteers, the other
of all the members of the House. For the latter picture the Censor acted as focusing object
in the centre of the room, but assured the members that such was not to be his position on the
picture.
Little interest was manifested in the debate.
The readiness with which the speakers, at
other meetings of the House, responded to
the arguments brought against them was notably absent. The men seemed to be in a leth-

argic spell. Possibly it was that the night's
carousing at the banquet, and the excitement
produced in trying to elude the freshmen, had
left their mark on the speakers. There were,
however, a few exceptions to the general listlessness. Messrs. Morgan and French argued
in a clear and convincing manner. Mr. Davidson, quoting Carlyle, said that the power of
our country lay in its wide expanse of territory. As the nation grows, it can extend itself. He further argued that, if immigration
were not restricted, our power would decrease
in proportion that our land became occupied
by foreign element, which would necessitate
the concentration of so many more inhabitants
to the square mile.
The Censor complimented the House on its
good order during the year, and stated that if
the members wished to pass the examination
at Easter that their presence at the contest was
essential.
The memorial tablet for Professor Humphrey and Dr. Conant has been put up on the
second floor of the Biological Laboratory.
Anyone wishing to contribute to the memorial
can give his share to Mr. Waters, the secretary of the Naturalists' Field 'Club. All those
who knew Professor Humphrey and Dr. Conant will surely be eager to help in keeping
bright their memory. It is, however, specified
that no one man should contribute more than
half a dollar. If the expenses should not be
covered in this way, the University will pay
the rest.
The debating teams of the Senate and
House are now beginning to acquire finishing
touches. Both teams, as Mr. Censor says, arc
now quite well versed in the subject matter.

AN EPISODE.

I.

(MABEL—AT HER DRESSING TABLE.)
I've lost my glove
Or let it drop by chance !
I had it last—oh! I remember—
Three nights ago at Bessie Wilson's dance,
While Ned was standing near
And with warm, pleading eyes
Besought me for a flower—
As trophy, sign or prize.
But I refused it ;
Told him "not to flirt 1"
Then stooped to see the stain
On my neiv velvet skirt.
Would he have dared to steal the glove
And keep it for a token?
But, dear! what horrid lurk it is
The new pair should be broken.
The others would have warmed his heart
Or filled as well the locket
In which—well,I declare 1
The glove's here in my pocket!

(NED—TO HIS PIPE.)
It was tempting. How tempting? Well, nobody knows,
As she stood there, eyes sparkling, cheeks
coleur de rose.
The flower I asked for—she said that she
wouldn't."
Yet even my dullness discerned that she
couldn't,
With old Mrs. Wilson, the tireless dragon,
Alert, vis-a-vis, with her tongue primed to
wag on.
Then over her frock, as she gracefully bent
To look at the stain, and, worse, at the rent
That I'd made when at supper, in feverish
rush,
I had wildly attempted to ward off the crush—
From her pocket there peeped just the end of
her glove—
The symbol in all time to lovers of love.

"CARJAC."
THE TROPHY ROOM.

In planning the gymnasium the trustees designed one room which should belong distinctively to the students. It was intended as a
place for the preservation and display of trophies won by Hopkins teams, and as a centre
for the social life of the students about the
gymnasium. The University, has provided
chairs and settees, a beautiful quartered oak
centre table, and a fine oak book case, and
have given the gymnasium committee permission to select engravings from the McCoy collection. Professor Adams has given a steel
engraving and gifts have been received from
the undergraduate classes. Many things, however, are yet needed.
A covering of some sort for the floor should
be provided, and a case in which the trophies
already available may be safely exhibited.
Racks for books and papers should be arranged and books on athletics solicited from
the generously inclined. THE NEWS-LETTER
will file the best of its exchanges in the room,
so that, in the accounts of their games with
other colleges, our athletes may "see themselves as others see them." Post-graduates,
too, may find these interesting. Appropriate
mantel ornaments—whatever, in fact, would
add to the attractiveness of the room—will be
highly appreciated.
These things will not come without effort.

Rev. Henry Van Dyke, D. D., LL. D.,
graduated from Princeton in 1873, and from
the Princeton Theological Seminary in 1877.
He also studied for two years at the University
of Berlin. In 1883 Dr. Van Dyke was appointed as preacher of Harvard University,
and in 1893 he delivered the Lyman Beecher
lectures on"Preaching"at Yale. Most of his
religious and philosophical works are read as
much across the waters as with us. His best
known critical work is the volume on "The
Poetry of Tennyson," published in 1889.

A MINIATURE.

By your own strict command and injunction
Your picture my wall may not grace.
Yet, alone, when gossips are absent
I may steal a swift glance at the face
Which art has made so like your own.
When the day's weary strivings are over,
And the duties that drive me are done,
And I sit in the firelight recalling
The deeds of the day, one by one,
And their measure of good and of ill,
Then I take from its guarded seclusion
That picture you gave me, dear friend,
And I make you the judge of my actions
And learn from your eyes if they tend
To the good, and the right and the true.
Full often your eyes seem to censure
Some deed, whose motive was mean;
Or an act, from honor diverging
Loses all its false glamour and sheen
'Neath the spell of your pure, maiden's glance.
God grant that the years may not lessen
Your faith in the strength of the right.
God grant me that time may not weaken
The mystic, the wonderful, might
Of a true woman's God-given power.

NEWS OF A FORTNIGHT.
HENRY GEORGE.

The session of the Economic Seminary, held
on February 25, was devoted to a study of the
life and writings of Henry George. Professor
Sherwood stated, on opening the Seminary,
that, however much public opinion may differ
as to the feasibility and practicability of
George's theories, neither his ability is doubted by one, nor the immense influence of his
theories upon public thought. From the efforts of George a new field in economics has
been opened up, in spite of the violent opposition of Walker and other prominent economists, who scouted the idea that such doctrines
could be included under the name of economics. Mr. Adams reviewed "Progress and Poverty," the greatest work of George. Mr.
Adams considered the fundamental defect of
the book was that it assumed everything static
except wealth and population. These premises
granted, George's conclusions appear logical—
but few will be willing to grant such conditions. Interesting reviews of various other
works of George were given by different members of the Seminary. In conclusion, Mr.
Niles, a prominent member of the Baltimore
bar, defended the single-tax theory. He considered it just that land, which is the primitive
form of wealth, should bear the burdens of taxation, while all other forms of wealth, since
they are created by man's exertions, should be
exempt. In other words, man's ingenuity and
thrift should not be discouraged by taxation.
Land, however, is not produced by man's exertion, and should pay the expenses of government from the "unearned increment of the
soil."

It is greatly to be regretted that the Legislature is faltering in the matter of appropriating financial aid to the University. There
is evidence of opposition to the appropriation
among a few people from the counties. This
can arise from only one cause—ignorance.
Misrepresentations of the kind that is given out
by that daily comic valentine known as the
World may influence some persons. This, of
all disreputable sheets, is at the top-notch of
yellow newspaper work. It deserves not to be
placed in the category of yellow journalism.
It is in line to say that all the other city papers
favor the appropriation. As to the merits of
the University's appeal, the strongest and
withal simplest argument is the list of some
thirteen hundred names of former students,
who have achieved prominence in business,
literature, science, medicine and law. There
is really no logical reason why the state should
not come to the rescue of the Johns Hopkins
University, which, more than any other institution in the State, has spread abroad the fame
of Baltimore and Maryland.
A committee of representative citizens from
Baltimore, of which Mr. Parr was chairman,
went to Annapolis in behalf of obtaining State

aid for the Johns Hopkins University. This
shows that the best citizens of Baltimore are
actively interested in the Hopkins, and we are
sure that this cannot fail to impress the Legislature favorably.
It is the intention of THE NEWS-LETTER
to take on its editorial board at Easter a few
members of the freshman class, that they may
have the opportunity to gain some experience and receive certain necessary training
for the proper carrying on of the work in the
coming year. By this association in the management with those already accustomed to the
work many of the difficulties naturally found
in the beginning of a year may be avoided, and
the paper will pass on to other hands without
giving undue evidence of the change, except
in what is hoped may be its steady improvement.
All of the men who wish to try for the position must write and hand in before Easter
some matter worthy of publication in THE
NEWS-LETTER. Any item of University news,
or an article on some question of interest to
the students here, may serve as subject matter.
By previous arrangement with the editor-inchief, some certain subject (as the hockey
games, etc.,) may be agreed upon. This will
test the fitness of the applicant for his work,
and among these applicants the new men will
be selected by the present board of editors.

ness of things, be given by other than those
standing at the head of her body politic. Coup
de grace it was, in the truest meaning of the
phrase ; and while the Board of Collegiate
Advisors may enjoy to the full the knowledge
that it was they who drove home the last thrust
into the prostrate form of this old enemy, the
credit for laying that enemy low can belong
only to our student body. It was the student
body that, at Princeton, carried through the
honor system in examination. And it is undoubtedly true of all such bodies of maturing
young men gathered together in colleges or
universities that a radical change in their traditional customs can be effected by no cut-anddried rules, laid down for them ; but only by
the concerted action of the men themselves.
In the present instance, it was the freshman
class to whOm fell the opportunity of taking
this decisive step. And to them belongs much
credit. But credit is also due to the juniors,
who laid aside all personal feeling in order to
aid in what they knew was for the best interests
of the Hopkins ; and some crumbs of credit
should also fall to the seniors and graduates
who at the right moment assumed the right attitude toward the question.

action, it is yet for the best, as it eliminates
any possible misinterpretation of the faculty's
attitude, and should avoid all false representation, in the press, of the spirit of our University life.

LACROSSE.

On Tuesday evening last Captain Robinson called a meeting of the lacrosse coaches.
Mr. Sidney Cone, the famous Druid goalkeeper, was elected head coach. His assistants are Messrs Johnson Poe, Berwick
Lanier, Thomas F. P. Cameron, Thomas Penniman, L. Warrington iCottman and James S.
Hodges. The coaches discussed the style of
play to be used, and promised to assist the
team in the cage and on the field.
NOTES.

The Johns Hopkins University was admitted to the Inter-collegiate Athletic Association of Amateur Athletes of America. The
annual convention was held the 26th of February in New York. Messrs. Garrett and
Scholl were the delegates.
Now that Hopkins is a member of this Association it is necessary to send at least three
men to the inter-collegiate meet in order to
maintain its membership.
The furniture has been put in the smokingroom in the gymnasium. This consists of
carved oak chairs and a book case, in which
will be placed books on sports, and sporting
magazines. The pictures of the old athletic
teams will be hung on the wall, and the place
will soon have quite a cosy appearance.

MEDICAL SCHOOL NOTES.

Cards have appeared during the past week
announcing the formal opening of the "Book
Department." This concern, which promises
to fill a long felt want, is a private enterprise
managed by Messrs. H. W. Carey and E. H.
Hume of the first year. At present orders for
books may be left at the Postoffice, but later
on, the Department is to have a room in the
new Physiological Building. It has the active
support of the authorities, and text books used
in the different courses will be kept on hand.
Special books will be ordered for individuals,
and arrangements have been made with the
leading American and European publishers
insuring the prompt delivery of books ordered,
and where possible at a reduction from the list
prices.
This arrangement will save time, money and
trouble for the student, and should insure their
hearty co-operation and trade.
Messrs. E. H. Hume and E. A. Wells, of the
first year, have been appointed assistants in
Physiological Chemistry.
Y. M. C. A.

Mr. Morris 1.. Barr, our delegate to the Students' Volunteer'Convention at Cleveland, has
returned, and reports a successful convention,
in which 448 colleges and universities were
represented by 2214 accredited delegates.
There were 22 delegates from Maryland, of
whom four—Miss Rose Fairbank, and Messrs.
C. W. Otley, Joseph Akerman, and E. A.
Wells—were from the Medical School. The
Woman's College sent three delegates. The
large number of representatives from the Medical School is explained by the fact that a considerable number of the students are preparing for work as medical missionaries, and
hence are vitally interested in the students' volunteer movement.

dates for the team are, in the main, working

It remains to be seen whether the junior team

brought forth at the contest would form the

A large attendance from the student body is

HOUSE.

The House met on Wednesday of last week.
It was virtually the last meeting, as the speakers on the team will take up the time at the
next session in showing the arguments they
have gathered. The team now consists of
Messrs. Morgan, French, Grimes, and Guggenheimer, and from these men the Censor
will make his choice as to who is to speak on
the day of contest.
The chief interest of the session centred in
the photographer of the Herald's staff. Two
pictures were taken—one of the team with the
advisory board and the volunteers, the other
of all the members of the House. For the latter picture the Censor acted as focusing object
in the centre of the room, but assured the members that such was not to be his position on the
picture.
Little interest was manifested in the debate.
The readiness with which the speakers, at
other meetings of the House, responded to
the arguments brought against them was notably absent. The men seemed to be in a leth-

argic spell. Possibly it was that the night's
carousing at the banquet, and the excitement
produced in trying to elude the freshmen, had
left their mark on the speakers. There were,
however, a few exceptions to the general listlessness. Messrs. Morgan and French argued
in a clear and convincing manner. Mr. Davidson, quoting Carlyle, said that the power of
our country lay in its wide expanse of territory. As the nation grows, it can extend itself. He further argued that, if immigration
were not restricted, our power would decrease
in proportion that our land became occupied
by foreign element, which would necessitate
the concentration of so many more inhabitants
to the square mile.
The Censor complimented the House on its
good order during the year, and stated that if
the members wished to pass the examination
at Easter that their presence at the contest was
essential.
The memorial tablet for Professor Humphrey and Dr. Conant has been put up on the
second floor of the Biological Laboratory.
Anyone wishing to contribute to the memorial
can give his share to Mr. Waters, the secretary of the Naturalists' Field 'Club. All those
who knew Professor Humphrey and Dr. Conant will surely be eager to help in keeping
bright their memory. It is, however, specified
that no one man should contribute more than
half a dollar. If the expenses should not be
covered in this way, the University will pay
the rest.
The debating teams of the Senate and
House are now beginning to acquire finishing
touches. Both teams, as Mr. Censor says, arc
now quite well versed in the subject matter.
